data.title: Roku: A Strategic Pivot May Be About To Unlock Major Upside Value
data.description:
Roku, Inc. (ROKU) announced its third quarter results yesterday after market close, and the response has not been particularly positive, with the stock falling from $100 to $94 in post-market trading as of this writing. I wanted to take a look in at the stock as I actually thought the report was a solid one. Why, then, the decline?

A Solid Earnings Report

Roku’s post-market fall might lead some to think that the earnings report was a disappointment, but I really don’t see it. The earnings report itself was fine. Roku reported another quarter of positive net income and, unlike last quarter, this time its operating income was positive as well. For the first time since 2021 in fact. Despite the Devices segment falling back into negative gross profit territory—it had pushed itself to break even in Q2—Platform profit growth was enough to take operating income to $9.5 million.

Obviously, for a company with a $15 billion market cap that still isn’t very high. But it could be a leading indicator of Roku crossing a tipping point. I believe the drivers of this improved performance are management’s decision to finally pivot to a more subscription-based business model. Since I’ve been arguing for a while that Roku’s advertising focus—which I know many have considered a positive—was actually a detriment to the company, I’m excited by this new turn. And since subscription, unlike advertising, is still in its very early innings, I’m actually impressed by that small $9.5 million number.

My Continuing Skepticism About Advertising

To be clear, I have never argued that Roku cannot generate substantial revenues from free ad-supported streaming television. Roku Channel continues to move up the ladder in Nielsen’s monthly “The Gauge” report of TV timeshare. In fact, Roku is now the leading streaming channel outside of the Big Four—that's YouTube, Amazon.com, Inc.’s (AMZN) Prime Video, Netflix, Inc. (NFLX) and The Walt Disney Company's (DIS) three separate—for now—services.

My concern has always been with how much profit that revenue will yield. I have written about this at length before, so only briefly: Roku’s lack of broad first-party data on its customers means that it cannot target advertisements at specific demos with the precision that Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) or a Google (GOOGL) (GOOG) could. I believe this means that Roku’s ad-supported service could only ever hope to run at break-even no matter how large it got. You can read more about how I analyzed the ad operation to arrive at these conclusions here.

Setting One Thing Straight Before We Dive In

The pushback to my “subs not ads” thesis from bulls has always been that Roku does have a lot of data to use, and certainly that has been management’s position. CEO Anthony Wood insisted yet again on today’s earnings conference call that “we have a lot of data” and also argued that “half of all TV streaming happens on our platform.” The implication is that someone who controls half of TV streaming must have some leverage they can use.

I just want to set the record straight on this one more time; Roku does have 50% household penetration, but it does not have 50% of the TV streaming time. This is because many households have devices from multiple manufacturers in their house; my parents have a Roku, an Amazon Fire TV and an Apple Inc.'s (AAPL) Apple Inc. in various rooms of their home. Wood himself later went back and expressed the number this correctly, “we’re in half the broadband households in the country,” which is accurate. But they do not control half of the streaming time.

A slightly more reliable indicator is the recent survey done by Pixalate, which shows that Roku controls 37% of the open programmatic ads sold on Connected TV devices. That’s a more reasonable estimate that closely aligns with my own research suggesting Roku has about 1/3 of the market. It’s also remarkably steady; a 2017 survey showed Roku with the exact same market share eight years ago.

The Pixalate shows Amazon Fire TV in third at 15%, which is not consistent with my estimates that Amazon controls nearly as large a market share as Roku. However, even Pixalate’s survey is not a complete picture; again, these are “open programmatic” sales, not total sales. Because Roku does not have reliable targeting data from first-party sales and search like Amazon and Google have, it sells more through this channel; Amazon’s market share is correspondingly underrepresented in a poll like this because they do have precise targeting data.

A Long-Awaited Advertising Strategy Shift

That’s probably why after several years of running in the red with their FAST service Roku Channel, Roku has finally decided to bow to the inevitable; the company announced in June that Roku would pool their addressable ad pods inside Amazon’s Demand-Side Platform. I consider this auspicious for Roku as it allows better monetization of their ad-supported viewing. Wood confirmed on the call that Amazon’s DSP integration “just” opened, which to me suggests that it probably wasn’t running until sometime in October. If what we are seeing in these numbers is all pre-Amazon, then the early return to operating income, even narrowly, is all the more impressive.

But if Amazon hasn’t kicked in yet, how did they do it? Management was effusive about the great work of the teams but typically vague about exactly where they’re getting the best results, which for competitive reasons I guess makes sense. But going by their actions, rather than their words, I think it's because they have finally shifted their focus to subscription, ad-free viewing, and by third quarter that transition already was underway.

Finally Embracing Subscriptions

Roku announced when it released its first-quarter earnings six months ago that it had entered into a firm agreement to buy the relatively economical skinny bundle TV service Frndly TV. The bundle offers live programming of a number of secondary channels that are neither sports, news nor broadcast. It is one of the few live services out there with plans below $10 per month.

Some have pointed to Frndly’s “live” status and said that this acquisition furthers Roku’s advertising ambitions. With respect, I don’t see it that way at all. Yes, Frndly offers live streams with ads. But hardly anyone watches that way, because Frndly has nothing that needs to be watched live and even most broadcast networks now see most of their scripted and reality content consumed on an on-demand basis.

Frndly’s real appeal to Roku almost certainly is the tech and features they have developed for subscription-based, ad-free viewing; an area in which Roku has little experience since it has, unwisely in my view, spent the past few years developing ad-supported tech stacks and techniques at the expense of any ad-free offering they might have been able to develop.

Even CBS, a channel with much more “heft” than Roku or Frndly, has confirmed that as much as 85% of the content that its streaming customers consume is on-demand, not live. For a non-sports/news service like Frndly you have to figure that number is a good deal higher still. 90%, at least. Perhaps 95%? 99?!?

And far from bemoaning that fact, Frndly management, who remain with the company post-closing, have positively leaned into it. Frndly offers Look Back, a 72-hour window to rewatch anything that has been broadcast on any of its channels, and a significant portion of its total content budget is allocated to services such as the Dove Channel, which offers all of its content ad-free on demand to subscribers.

Make no mistake, Frndly is an SVOD service, not an AVOD service. In fact, if not in name. And I think that is precisely why Roku wanted it. It is certainly why I wasn’t unhappy to hear they were acquiring it.

Howdy To You, Too

Roku followed up with the launch of Howdy in August. The name notwithstanding, it’s another exciting development as far as I’m concerned. Howdy is a true SVOD service, a la Netflix, Inc. (NFLX) without even Frndly’s largely superfluous live channel offerings.

The reason I consider this a further step is because of Roku’s data. As I said, contrary to management’s protestations, it’s almost certainly not detailed enough to target advertisements effectively. But the one category of data that Roku does have in considerable quantities is viewership data. Roku knows what its customers search for in its Voice Remotes, what they watch on Roku Channel, and, depending on where they find it, sometimes even what they’re watching on other apps.

The best use for this data is targeting content, not targeting advertisements. But with Roku Channel, they couldn’t turn a profit on content, and with Frndly they can’t decide what content they get—Lifetime and others program their own channels, Frndly/Roku merely act as broadcaster and salesman.

With Howdy, Roku will finally pair ad-free subscriptions with their own content curation efforts. While they’re a long way from being the next Netflix, content curation has considerable potential to yield an enduring profit margin for a subscription video service even without top-tier ad-targeting capabilities, because content recommendations can become a self-sustaining internal virtuous cycle in a way that advertising, an intrinsically three-party process, cannot. I wrote before about how the real profit of SVOD, unlike AVOD, lies not in quantity, but in intensity and fungibility of viewership.

Crucial to that is a recommendation engine that becomes embedded in consumers' behavioral expectations. Roku needs to prove to viewers that when they want “something” to watch, as opposed to a specific something, Howdy can find them a suitable piece of content with a minimum amount of wasted browsing time. On the earnings call Roku management also indicated that, while it's still early, they’ve seen good results with their decision to upgrade the recommendations engine to the top row of their eponymous home screen. That too is the right move, and I expect it will continue to bear fruit.

A Very Preliminary Estimate

Precisely because it’s so early, putting numbers on exactly how much profit Roku can generate from this is a little harder. Howdy is a $3 per month service, at least to start, and it won’t be profitable until it achieves critical mass. However, with the Q3 report out we do now see the first full quarter of Frndly TV’s operations.

Despite their press release and earnings call today, Roku has not yet filed their official Q3 10-Q at the time of writing, so I don’t have all the data I would like. For now, I am going to use an imputation model based on the assumption that Howdy will be programmed to produce a similar profit per subscriber to Frndly TV.

In Q2, management disclosed that Frndly represented roughly 1.8 percentage points of the growth in the Platform segment the company had seen, or roughly $15 million. That was for almost exactly two months. At Frndly’s price of $11 per month on their standard, mid-tier plan that comes to roughly 700,000 subscribers.

I continue to believe, as I’ve calculated in prior articles, that Roku’s subscription business is of sufficient size to justify its current market cap. If 700,000 Frndly subscribers can produce $38 million of increased income per year ($9.5 million times four) then at a 25 P/E that is worth almost $1 billion in additional market cap. Currently, Roku and Amazon are performing similarly in the CTV market, and Amazon has roughly 1/3 of Netflix’s viewership in the US. That would suggest Howdy and Frndly together might be able to get to as many as 25 million subscribers in the US. That would be enough to increase market cap by $35 billion, more than tripling Roku’s current share price!

That seems optimistic to me; I suspect these numbers are slanted by the fact that Roku and Amazon both report to the Nielsen Gauge not only their own viewership but also the premium subscriptions—HBO Max, Peacock, etc.—that are routed through their platforms. If we assume they represent half the viewership reported, SVOD will “only” double Roku’s market cap.

Investment Summary

For the past few years, I have been following a straightforward approach to Roku: ride the rollercoaster. That’s not always a good thing in stock trading, but when the highs and lows hold firm it can be very lucrative. I have an entry point around $60 and a sell point around $100. Three times in the past two years, Roku has run right up to the edge of the $100 point, and each time it has done so rebounding off of a sub-$60 floor. It's been possible to simply rinse and repeat.

I am wondering if this pattern is starting to break down. The release of Roku’s second-quarter earnings sent the stock plunging even though they came in mostly better than expected. It went back below $80. But then it rebounded back to $100.

Now it reports another good earnings, the stock falls again anyway….but only to $94. It’s been quite a while since Roku saw the sub-$60 range. And the developments of recent weeks suggest that perhaps it won’t again anytime soon.

I confess to being torn. I’m considerably more positive on Roku now than I was before they pivoted from advertising to subscription. But my high-low formula has been a consistent performer for the past few years. Should I abandon it and buy in now, or await a future dip?

I am honestly unsure. When torn between a weak Buy and a strong Hold, I usually opt for the latter to avoid buying something I lack complete conviction in. But the truth is I don’t lack conviction in Roku’s upside; I just question whether it will be even cheaper later than it is now.

I have not yet bought in, but I may today. I’ll see how it opens, but regardless of whether it returns to its floor again or not, I believe Roku is finally ready to break through its ceiling in the coming months. As such, while I am not completely sure of the timing of my next Roku purchase yet, I am going to give it a Buy rating.

data.title: Lufthansa: FCF Beat, Steady Execution, SOTP Still Compelling -- Buy Reaffirmed
data.description:
Following our update on Deutsche Lufthansa AG's (OTCQX:DLAKF) (OTCQX:DLAKY) Capital Market Day, we provide a further update on the Q3 German flag carrier results. For our new readers, Lufthansa is one of the largest airlines, and its network airlines segment includes SWISS, ITA, Austrian, Brussels Airlines, and a low-cost operator called Eurowings. Additionally, Lufthansa offers aviation services such as Cargo, MRO, and catering.

Lufthansa’s CMD set ambitious margin ambitions, a leaner fleet plan, and clear priorities across business segments. Management expressed confidence in exceeding pre-COVID margin levels, underpinned by a stronger balance sheet, improving FCF, and rising shareholder payouts. At today’s market value, the MRO franchise alone accounts for a large share of the enterprise value.

Q3 Results

In Q3, Lufthansa Group's top-line sales were €11.2 billion, up 11% from the previous year. As the company reported, "this was the strongest quarter in terms of revenue in the history of the Lufthansa Group." EBIT reached €1.3 billion, which was at the previous year's level; however, EBIT margin declined by 60 basis points to 11.9%. Passenger yields were weaker at -5.4% and dragged down by Europe and North America. On a positive note, Lufthansa Cargo continued its positive trajectory with an EBIT of €49 million. Meanwhile, the Lufthansa Technik [MRO] segment reported an EBIT decrease. The division reached an EBIT of €130 million. Going down to the P&L, the company's net profit amounted to €966 million as tax weighed into results.

Source: Lufthansa Q3 results ppt - Fig 1

Why Are We positive?

The company's quarterly results look fine, though the first read skews more negative than positive. However, digging into the report, we remain constructive for the following reason:

MRO Upside Is Still There, And Supportive Cost-Management

The MRO division's core operating profit decreased to €130 million compared to €161 million in Q3 2024. Higher tariffs, a weaker dollar, and additional costs to production ramp-up negatively impacted the segment. That said, top-line sales were up by 10%, and the company reported a solid order book. Looking forward (Fig. 2), Lufthansa won maintenance contracts with EasyJet and Cathay Group.

Within the adjusted EBIT detail, Pax Airlines delivered a flat performance compared to Q3 2024. This result was achieved with ex-fuel unit costs up to 0.5% and should be positively received.

Fig 2

FCF And Deleverage Path

Q3 FCF was materially higher than expected, reaching €818 million (Fig. 1). So, net debt (including pension) fell to €7.2 billion compared to a Q3 2024 of €8.3 billion (Fig. 3). Net pension fell to €2.1 billion, with liquidity higher than €900 million to €11.9 billion. Here at the Lab, we believe this is just the beginning, and this high conviction is reinforced by LHA's turnaround plan to save at least €1.5 billion (Fig. 4).

Fig 3

Pick-up In Airline Search Trends

Cross-checking Google search, new evidence suggests that airline searches have become more popular. The latest trends support Lufthansa very well in Germany and Italy compared to last year, while there is a slight decrease in Spain. This is supportive evidence for the company. Indeed, the company reaffirmed its 2025 full-year forecast.

Fig 4

Valuation

All in, a second pass shows a robust delivery that supports our constructive view. The company confirmed its yearly guidance and reported a higher EBIT than in 2024 (which reached €1.64 billion). Considering this print, Lufthansa's core operating profit amounted to €1.5 billion year-to-date, up by €300 million compared to last year's level. Q4 is a strong quarter for Pax Airlines and Cargo, while it is softer on MRO. Recent booking trends also suggest higher volumes. Our valuation is backed by a sum-of-the-parts thesis, which includes the airlines and MRO segment. On a YTD results, the airlines generated an EBIT of €1.2 billion, and are targeting a 1.6-1.7 billion result by year-end. While the MRO division has an €800 million core operating profit performance. Considering the Cargo business, we believe a €3 billion core operating profit is still achievable.

As reported in our Q3 results paragraph, there was a higher tax rate in the third quarter; however, we applied the corporate tax rate of 25%. So, our income projections are set at €2.1 billion, which derives an EPS of €1.75. With no change to our valuation methodology (6x P/E target), Lufthansa's price is confirmed at €10.5 per share ($12.15 in ADR).

Lufthansa's current market cap is €8.6 billion. As a reminder, a group of private equity firms tried to acquire the MRO division, valuing the subsidiary at approximately $8.7 billion (€7.5 billion). Considering the evolution of FCF, the company will likely exceed its FCF target of €800 million with a potential further debt repayment. We are not underwriting 2026 yet (with supportive evidence from the CMD update). Still, aside from ongoing cost optimization, there is also a higher capacity in 2026, with the company expecting an increase of 4%.

Risks

Our downside risks include the company's ongoing restructuring initiatives, estimated at €1.5 billion, and higher competition from low-cost operators. Lufthansa's risks are also lower due to lower travel demand from business and leisure, changes in oil prices, wage inflation, higher regulatory standards and airport costs, FX changes, and all the negative event risks related to travel, such as airport shutdowns, cybersecurity risks, natural catastrophes, and terrorist actions/attacks.

Conclusion

Q3 results de-risk Lufthansa's investment thesis, and there is upside valuation to consider. Following the CMD release, the company has a clear earnings/transforming roadmap for delivery. Therefore, our buy rating is confirmed.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Wasatch Long/Short Alpha Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Portfolio Manager

Mick Rasmussen, CFA

Lead Portfolio Manager

Overview

In the third quarter, U.S. small-cap stocks rallied sharply. The Federal Reserve’s interest rate cut helped lift stocks, as did economic data showing that, while there may be some pockets of concern, the U.S. economy remained steady. In this environment, the Russell 2500 TM Index was up 9.00%. The Wasatch Long/Short Alpha Fund—Investor Class (WALSX) did not keep pace and finished the period down -7.25%.

The quarter was indeed a challenging one for the Fund. In what we would characterize as a very strong “risk-on” environment, the stocks of low-quality companies outperformed the stocks of high-quality businesses. This was a structural headwind for our Fund, which aims to be long on high-quality companies, and to short the stocks of companies we perceive as low quality.

As we explain more in our Outlook section, we believe such positioning will serve us well through the investment cycle. But when low quality outperforms high quality, and when stocks we view as more speculative experience the highest returns, it works against the Fund in two ways. First, our long positions, which again we consider high quality, underperform the benchmark. Second, when we short stocks we perceive as low quality and those stocks rise, our short positions also detract from performance. This dynamic was in play throughout the quarter, in an environment we believe was as speculative and euphoric as the post-Covid market rebound in late 2020 and early 2021.

Given the magnitude of this headwind on Fund performance, we wanted to share a little more detail on the strength of the low-quality rally. As we mentioned last quarter, stocks have rallied sharply since mid-April. And for the most part, the stocks of lower quality companies have been leading the charge.

Many of the top-performing stocks in recent months have been those of companies that have speculative business models, in our view, and often have little to no earnings. They’re often tied to popular investment themes such as artificial intelligence (AI), quantum computing, cryptocurrency, nuclear power, aerospace and defense.

The chart below shows how extreme a headwind this has been. The chart displays one of the ways Wasatch’s research team assesses whether high- or low-quality stocks are in favor. Through a proprietary process, we screen and rank all the companies in the small- and mid-cap universe based on several financial characteristics, such as return on assets and operating profit margins, among other items. Using the aggregate score we obtain, we then compare how the companies in the top quintile perform relative to the bottom quintile. Based on this metric, we’ve rarely seen a low-quality rally approach this magnitude over the past decade.

Additionally, a few statistics point to how low quality has been in favor. The statistics are for the Russell 2000® Growth Index, which is the benchmark for some of our U.S.-focused small cap strategies. For the third quarter, 56 stocks were up 80% or more. Of that group, 82% are unprofitable, and 57% within the group trade at a multiple of 10 times sales or greater. We view this multiple, which looks at revenue and not earnings, as extreme.

We can’t predict when the period favoring the stocks of low-quality companies will end. But periods of low-quality outperformance have historically been short-lived. The stocks of high-quality businesses have outperformed over the long term. We believe that will continue to be the case.

Details of the quarter

Among our long positions, one of the largest detractors was Inspire Medical Systems, Inc. (INSP). Inspire develops implantable neurostimulators for treating obstructive sleep apnea. The company’s shares slid in August after management downgraded full-year 2025 guidance due to delays in the U.S. commercial rollout of its next-generation Inspire V system. The delayed rollout of Inspire V raised questions about execution by management and caused us to trim the position. Additionally, concerns are growing about how GLP-1 drugs may affect Inspire’s addressable market.

Another detractor was Shift4 Payments, Inc. (FOUR). A longtime holding in many of our small-cap funds, Shift4 is a U.S. company that provides payment processing solutions for hospitality, retail and e-commerce businesses. Fundamentals for the company remain solid, as organic revenues grew in the high-teens percentages in the most recent quarter. But the stock has been down in part due to concerns about how a softer macroeconomic environment could affect the company. Additionally, investor sentiment on the company became less favorable after its acquisition of Global Blue, which is a foray into a new customer segment for Shift4. The acquisition also means the company is taking on more debt. Acquisitions can sometimes cause investors angst since they take time to integrate into a company’s normal operations. However, we have confidence in Shift4’s leadership and their ability to execute on Global Blue.

Freshpet, Inc. (FRPT) also detracted. The company manufactures refrigerated dog and cat food and treats. In general, pet owners have been less willing to pay for premium fresh pet food in the current economic environment. However, we continue to like the company. Even in today’s environment, we’ve seen Freshpet take market share from other premium pet foods. And we believe investments the company has made to expand its manufacturing footprint have reached a tipping point that could drive cashflows meaningfully higher.

Medpace Holdings (MEDP) was the top contributor to Fund performance during the quarter. The contract research organization provides drug development, clinical trial management, and regulatory services to biotech, pharmaceutical, and medical device companies. Medpace’s shares jumped after management reported strong revenue and earnings growth and raised its full-year guidance. We believe those results are particularly impressive in light of the fact there’s been a slowdown in the biotech funding cycle.

Another top contributor was Fabrinet (FN). The company designs, manufactures, and tests complex optoelectronic and photonic components, modules, and precision optical assemblies for customers in a variety of industries. Some of its products are used in data centers, which makes the company tied somewhat to AI. As mentioned, this has been a popular theme among investors, and likely helped drive the stock higher. However, we don’t hold the stock as a thematic play on AI. The company is experiencing strong adoption of its products with both new and existing customers. We believe Fabrinet is well positioned to grow regardless of AI.

Turning to short positions, detractors from Fund performance were those stocks that rose in price. One of the largest detractors was Opendoor Technologies, Inc. (OPEN). The company operates a digital real estate platform that provides services for buying and selling residential properties online. We viewed the company as lower quality, given questions about the viability of the business model, and shorted the stock to offset some of our long positions tied to the housing industry. However, Opendoor became a “meme stock” popular among investors in Reddit investment forums and the stock price rose as investors piled in. We did not want to invest against that type of market dynamic and quickly covered the short position.

Among shorts, contributors to Fund performance were those stocks that declined in price. One of the largest contributors was Sweetgreen, Inc. (SG), a fast-casual restaurant chain that specializes in made-to-order salads and grain bowls. We short the position as a hedge against some of our long positions in the consumer-discretionary and consumer-staples sectors. Companies in these sectors can be impacted when consumer spending turns weak. And this quarter, most stocks of restaurant companies were indeed down due to such concerns. (Current and future holdings are subject to risk and change.)

Outlook and Positioning

While performance this period was painful, we wouldn’t expect the Fund to keep up in what we view as an extreme risk-on environment. We’re seeing a lot of capital flow to companies with highly speculative business models, where there may not even be a commercially viable product or service yet—just a research department and a business plan. In our view, the amount of speculation in the market today is eerily similar to that of the internet bubble, or the post-Covid environment in late 2020 and 2021.

However, the speculation that has taken place leaves us excited about the Fund’s return potential from here. The run up in stock prices of what we believe are low-quality businesses has given us an opportunity to short stocks that look extremely overpriced. And on the long side, our companies have generally continued to generate strong earnings growth, though we believe fundamentals have mattered less to investors in a speculative market.

Given the way we feel about the portfolio and the market environment, we’ve increased the Fund’s gross exposure, and have done so by increasing both long and short exposure. We can’t predict when the current speculative, risk-on environment will subside. But when it does, we believe the Fund is well positioned for it.

Thank you for the opportunity to manage your assets.

Sincerely,

Mick Rasmussen

data.title: AMD: 200% Price Jump Meets Q3 2025 Earnings (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
In my last coverage, I rated Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) as a Strong Buy after the 6GW deal with OpenAI (OPENAI) finally turned around the sentiment surrounding this company, historically perceived as a distant second to Nvidia (NVDA).

Since the lows in April, shares are up by over 200%, outperforming Nvidia (115% return in the same period).

With OpenAI likely to become a 10% shareholder after the compute and price milestones are achieved (remember the last price threshold is $600) and the ramp of the MI350 series until (at least) the back end of the year, I believe there is still room for multiple expansion. Looking at 2026, the MI400 series will likely fuel another growth cycle in the data center segment, so the high forward P/E multiple doesn't make me sweat.

In this piece, I break down the key items to watch in the upcoming earnings release expected on November 4th and share my take on the MI308 export situation in China.

Overall, I remain bullish on the stock, although I warn that a healthy pullback post Q4 earnings results is not completely off the charts. Considering the strong fundamentals of the company, I strongly believe that such a pullback will be short-lived.

Q3 2025 Preview

Here are the items that I would keep a very close eye on.

On the top line, management guided Q3 revenue to be approximately $8.7 billion, plus or minus $300 million. At the midpoint, that would represent an impressive 13% sequential revenue growth. The Street expects revenue to come in slightly higher, at $8.75B.

On the bottom line, management guided non-GAAP gross margin to be approximately 54% in Q3, with operating expenses projected to land around $2.55B. In line with the historical reporting trends of the company, management didn't guide EPS. All we have are the Street's projections, which suggest a midpoint of $1.17 EPS.

The MI 350 ramp will likely be the main theme of the earnings call. In fact, management apparently expects this ramp to be the single most important factor for the strong double-digit top line growth of the data center segment. Please note that the improvement is on a sequential basis (i.e., QOQ rather than YOY), which is a clear indication of the momentum in this segment.

I still see plenty of momentum left from the ramp of the MI350 series, as confirmed by CEO Lisa Su in the last earnings call:

We began volume production of the MI350 series ahead of schedule in June and expect a steep production ramp in the second half of the year to support large-scale production deployments with multiple customers.

Management is not as bullish on the growth of the client segment, though. The expectations set in Q2 suggest single-digit percentage growth (again, sequentially). As seen below, the growth rate in this segment is even more impressive than in the data center business, but it seems to have now stabilized. I can't complain considering the 67% YOY growth in Q2.

As for the gaming segment, management expects flattish growth (sequentially) in Q3. This segment outperformed in Q2, mainly due to an increase in semi-custom revenue and strong AMD Radeon GPU demand. Interestingly enough, the momentum in this segment is projected to remain at the same levels in Q3, but Q4 will likely be a rough quarter.

Here are the CEO's remarks from the latest Q&A:

As we go into the fourth quarter, the dynamics that we would see is we would see that the console business would actually be down substantially, so think about it as down strong double digits. Our customers usually build for the holiday season in -- sort of before that, and then that will be completed by the fourth quarter. So we would expect as the Client and Gaming segment, that the segment would probably be down in the fourth quarter.

The words "down substantially" are not encouraging, but consider that gaming was just 14.5% of the consolidated revenue in Q2. The narrative of the company is mainly driven by the data center segment, and that's where the focus in Q3 will be.

The Risks To Monitor

Let's start with China. Management said that MI308 sales to China were effectively eliminated from their projections. If you look at the chart from the previous section showing the data center AI segment, you may notice that the top line growth declined from 57.2% YOY in Q1 2025 to 14.3% YOY in Q2. The main driver was the export controls affecting the MI308 GPU to China.

A quick look at the latest 10-K shows a table with sales to external customers by geographic regions:

China ranks second on that list by revenue weight, trailing the U.S. by just under $2.5 billion. An update on the exports to China is highly anticipated by the Street, although I wouldn't expect management to include China revenue in their guidance for Q4. Why?

In my view, chips are the main leverage the U.S. holds over China in the November 10 negotiations. Since AMD reports earnings on November 4, I see little to no chance that Lisa Su will include MI308 sales to China in Q4. Furthermore, recent reporting indicates the U.S. and China agreed to keep the truce in place rather than letting it lapse on November 10. In other words, even if AMD and Nvidia were cleared to resume exports of certain AI accelerators to China in August in exchange for a 15% "tax" to the US government, I wouldn't expect a significant uplift from China in the near term. Why?

In the last Q&A session, Lisa pointed out:

We do expect that once those licenses are approved, we will start MI308 shipments. In terms of the supply chain, most of our inventory was not in finished goods, so it was work in process, and it will take us a couple of quarters to run through that. The exact timing of revenue and contribution will depend a bit on when those are -- when the licenses are actually granted.

Her remark that "it will take us a couple of quarters to run through that" is not encouraging to me. Therefore, I wouldn't expect sales in China to return this year.

This means that the $800 million inventory charge tied to export restrictions will continue to pressure gross margins. Speaking of which, the Q2 GAAP gross margin was 43%, a 1000 bps decline compared to the same value in Q2 2024.

The guidance that I mentioned in the previous section for Q3 (the 54% non-GAAP gross margin) excludes the $800M inventory charge due to export controls to China. To be clear, AMD did not give a GAAP gross-margin target for Q3.

In comparison, Nvidia's gross margin is over 70%, and management's guidance is mid-70% before year's end. Speaking of Nvidia, let's take a look now at valuations.

Valuation

If we put the two giants side by side, there is a clear winner on a valuation basis.

That winner is Nvidia. As seen above, AMD trades at a 1-year forward P/E multiple of 115 vs. Nvidia's 47 multiple. Paying close to 3x more for AMD when Nvidia's growth prospects next year are about 3x higher than AMD's doesn't make much sense to me. That's why I prefer Nvidia over AMD.

Looking Ahead

AMD is scheduled to report Q3 2025 earnings after market close next Tuesday, November 4. Since the AMD–OpenAI 6GW partnership, announced on October 6, shares have been on the rise.

As I discussed in my previous article, OpenAI received a warrant for up to 160 million AMD shares (representing approximately a 10% ownership), vesting against compute and price milestones. This lifted shareholder optimism, as reflected in the recent price action. While I wouldn't completely discard a pullback post earnings, I believe it will be short-lived. That said, I downgrade my AMD rating to a Buy, as the risk of a pullback has increased since my last coverage.

data.title: The U.S. Dollar Gets More Fuel From Powell's Doubts About December Rate Cut
data.description:
The US dollar was already zigzagging higher against other currencies since the intensely hyped “debasement trade” had died a few weeks ago. Then Powell threw more fuel on the dollar on Wednesday by shedding doubts on the already taken-for-granted rate cut in December.

The debasement-trade promos in the financial and social media had exhorted people to pile into cryptos, gold, silver, and sometimes even stocks because government borrowing and money printing would rapidly erode the value of the US dollar. As in all these trades, if enough people follow, prices of the targeted instruments would explode, at least for a little while, and people that could get out in time would make lots of money.

But the huge bond market brushed off the debasement trade, and the dollar started zigzagging higher in late September. Then came Powell.

“A further reduction in the policy rate at the December meeting is not a forgone conclusion, far from it,” Powell said in his prepared remarks at the FOMC press conference on Wednesday.

Then, in response to a question, he said: "So, we are at a place where we’ve cut two more times. Now we are 150 basis points closer to neutral, whatever that may be, than we were a year ago. There is a growing chorus now of feeling like maybe this is where we should at least wait a cycle."

Upon which the dollar rose further against other currencies and continued that way on Thursday.

The DXY Dollar Index [DXY] rose 0.4% on Wednesday and again 0.4% on Thursday to 99.6, the highest since the brief spike at the end of July, and before then the highest since May. The DXY tracks the USD against the euro, yen, British pound, Canadian dollar, Swedish krona, and Swiss franc.

The long view of the DXY going back to its beginning in the early 1970s shows that this level of the dollar is just where it had been when the DXY index was introduced.

The dollar had been far lower against these currencies for many years during that time and far higher for some years.

The years 2022, 2023, and 2024 were among the high-water marks, with December 31, 2024, being the high of the year. And in the first half of 2025, the DXY declined from those relatively high levels on December 31.

The decline from December 31 through June 30 was far from being the biggest six-month decline in 50 years, as had been wrongly stated in the debasement trade promos for manipulative purposes. There were many six-month declines that were bigger, including in 2023 and 2020. But by coincidence of the calendar, it was the biggest decline from a December 31 through a June 30.

The WSJ Dollar Index [BUXX], which is far broader than the DXY, rose by 0.4% on Wednesday and 0.5% on Thursday, to 96.7, the highest since the brief spike at the end of July, and before then the highest since May.

The BUXX is trade-weighted and tracks the USD against the 16 currencies of the Euro Area, Japan, China, Canada, Mexico, South Korea, Taiwan, India, Hong Kong, Singapore, the UK, Australia, New Zealand, Norway, Switzerland, and Sweden.

The Fed’s policy interest rates, at 3.75% to 4.0%, are among the highest of the developed economies. They’re about double the ECB’s key rate of 2.0%. The BOJ at its meeting on Thursday held its key policy rate at 0.5%, barely above ZIRP, despite inflation accelerating and running at about the same pace as in the US.

As a result of the BOJ’s willfully lax policy, the yen has been getting crushed. The yen on Thursday dropped to ¥154 to the USD, the worst since February. Over the past five years, the yen lost 35% of its value against the USD. That has been the proper debasement trade for years.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: TSMC: You're Buying At Peak Valuation
data.description:
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM) remains one of the world's most critical companies for the semiconductor ecosystem. Its technological leadership at 3nm and 2nm nodes, unrivaled customer base that includes Nvidia (NVDA), Apple (AAPL), AMD (AMD), and consistently high margins have made it the backbone of the latest AI hardware boom.

However, after its stock rallied by around 50% since the beginning of the year, it is now priced for perfection. Currently, TSMC trades at over 29 times its forward earnings, similar to premium U.S. tech companies, despite operating in a region facing escalating geopolitical tensions and expanding capital intensity. Although the short-term demand for AI chips remains significant, the company faces challenges that can undermine its further upside. After all, its free cash flow is falling, capital expenditures are at record highs, and profitability will likely face headwinds as overseas fabs ramp up production of new chips. Because of that, we continue to rate TSMC as a sell.

New Challenges On The Horizon

There’s no denying that TSMC’s Q3 results were strong, as its revenues increased by 41% Y/Y to $33.1 billion, while gross margin rose to 59.5% and net margin reached nearly 46%. In addition, advanced nodes (7nm and below) now account for 74% of wafer revenue, with AI-related demand driving much of the growth. As a result of this, TSMC’s management even raised its full-year revenue forecast to over a 30% revenue growth rate, mostly thanks to the continuous AI tailwinds.

However, there are several things that can undermine TSMC’s further upside. Currently, the market is pricing TSMC as if its annual growth of over 30% will continue indefinitely, which we believe is an unlikely scenario given the cyclical nature of the semiconductor business. History shows that every foundry refresh cycle, even one driven by significant technological shifts, has been followed by a normalization of the growth rate once demand subsides. With AI wafer orders from Nvidia, AMD, and Apple expected to remain flat in 2026, TSMC’s growth next year could slow significantly, while costs will likely remain high.

After all, TSMC’s CapEx for 2025 has been raised again to $40-42 billion, which is almost in line with its forecasted annual free cash flow. Over 70% of this spending is directed at advanced technologies (3nm, 2nm, A16) and CoWoS packaging, while 10-20% is for funding the fab expansion primarily in the US, Japan, and Germany. While these investments are critical to maintaining leadership, they pose two structural challenges. First, free cash flow is being squeezed since TSMC generated only $4.3 billion in free cash flow in Q3 despite having record profits. Secondly, the erosion of overseas fab profitability is also a major issue. The management currently estimates that margins from operations outside Taiwan will reduce gross margin by 2-3% by 2026. This means that even with revenue growth, each new dollar of sales provides a lower return on invested capital.

Finally, the effectiveness of these investments has increasingly been questioned as numerous projects have faced cost overruns, labor shortages, and infrastructure delays. The Arizona plant, originally budgeted at $12 billion and initially expected to start production in 2024, was pushed back to 2025 due to a shortage of qualified technicians. Similarly, a second Japanese plant (JASM Phase 2) has been delayed by up to 18 months, pushing mass production to 2029 due to inadequate local infrastructure and logistical inefficiencies. This raises structural concerns about declining return on investment (ROIC) and future margin compression.

In addition to that, despite expanding its U.S. operations, TSMC still remains highly vulnerable to tensions between China and Taiwan. About 70% of its production still takes place on the island in East Asia, and management has repeatedly acknowledged that Taiwan remains indispensable for integrating advanced processes. As such, any escalation in the Taiwan Strait could disrupt the global semiconductor supply chain. So far, the market has been complacent about this risk. While Nvidia and Broadcom are geographically diversified and are not capital-heavy businesses, TSMC bears the brunt of both geopolitical risks and capital intensity, and yet it still trades at similar multiples to those two companies.

At more than 31x forward earnings and 18x EV/EBITDA, TSMC is now valued closer to Nvidia or Apple than its historical average of 20-22x. This multiple expansion assumes sustained revenue growth of 30-40% and stable margins of 60%, which we believe is unrealistic given rising CAPEX and potentially higher costs of running business outside Taiwan. The market is effectively pricing TSMC as if it were a geopolitically agnostic company that’s operating only in the United States, which is not the case. Right now, TSMC is a company that operates in an environment of increasing regional risks. Even with an unrivaled technical edge, the company, in our opinion, cannot command the same valuation premium as its Western customers.

Risks To Our Bearish Thesis

There are several factors that could cast doubt on our pessimistic outlook. The AI demand curve could continue to surprise from the bottom up, supporting wafer utilization and pricing for longer than we expect. Also, the company’s dominance in the CoWoS packaging industry makes it possible to benefit from the growth in demand for AI accelerators, where capacity remains limited. In addition, TSMC’s N2 and A16 nodes could also enter mass production ahead of schedule, providing another wave of unrivaled technological leadership.

The Real Value Of TSMC

To find out TSMC’s fair value, we built a valuation model at a time when the stock was trading at $305.09 per share. The model assumes a 3% terminal growth rate, consistent with the rate that we used when valuing other semiconductor companies. Our forecast covers the next 5 years and incorporates inputs such as cash and total debt from the most recent earnings report.

The model applies a discount rate of 8.43%, derived from TSMC’s estimated cost of equity and cost of debt. The cost of debt was based primarily on TTM data, while the cost of equity was calculated using the CAPM method with a risk-free rate of 4.10%, a beta of 1.22, and a market return rate of 7.77%.

Our revenue and EBIT projections for TSMC over the next 5 years are broadly similar to the overall consensus estimates. We also anticipate a gradual decline in EBIT margins, as macroeconomic headwinds and seasonal fluctuations could weigh on profitability. In our model, we also applied a 15% tax rate, in line with the assumptions used in our prior valuation models. The CapEx is projected to be around 41.8 billion in 2025, which is close to the management estimates. The change in net working capital is modeled at 5% of sales. Based on these inputs, our model estimates TSMC’s enterprise value to be $871.15 billion and its equity value to be $930.02 billion, which implies an intrinsic value of $179.19 per share.

In addition to this model, we also conducted a comparative valuation analysis using a peer group of semiconductor companies. The peer group included leading companies such as NVIDIA, AMD, Micron, and Broadcom, as well as tier-2 players such as Texas Instruments, NXP Semiconductors, ASE Technology, and United Microelectronics, among others.

Our analysis relied on three primary valuation ratios: price-to-sales (P/S), price-to-earnings (P/E), and EV/EBITDA. By comparing TSMC’s current trading multiples to the median of this peer group, we estimated the company’s relative fair value. The median of peers suggests a valuation of $101.00 per share based on a P/S, $238.58 per share based on a P/E, and $230.80 per share based on an EV/EBITDA.

Averaging these three approaches yields a fair value estimate of $190.14 per share. Equating the peer multiple and DCF model (50/50) methods to the methods most relevant to the semiconductor business yields a fair value estimate of $184.66 per share, indicating a 39.5% discount to the current market price.

Final Thoughts

Although TSMC has been performing great in recent quarters, its stock is priced for perfection. The company’s reliance on cyclical demand for AI, record CapEx, and geopolitical risks could make it more challenging for it to perform well in the following years. Even if TSMC remains a technological leader in the semiconductor industry, the combination of increased spending, higher costs from overseas expansion, and other rising risks leaves little room for further growth. Considering that at today’s price, TSMC offers more risks than rewards, we decided to continue to rate its stock as a sell.

data.title: A Surprise Big Drop In Italian Inflation
data.description:
By Paolo Pizzoli, Senior Economist, Italy, Greece

Preliminary data for October show Italian headline inflation slowing markedly to 1.2% year-on-year, down from 1.6% in September, a deceleration well beyond expectations. The main drivers were a pronounced slowdown in regulated energy and fresh food prices, more than offsetting the acceleration in prices for recreational, cultural, and personal care services. Core inflation, which excludes fresh food and energy, remained stable at 2%.

Goods prices slowed to just 0.2% year-on-year, while service inflation held steady at 2.6%, widening the gap between the two to 0.4 percentage points.

Today’s data confirms that the energy component remains pivotal in shaping the overall inflation trajectory. A comparison with gas and electricity prices recorded over the last two months of 2024 suggests that this base effect is unlikely to fade soon.

The stability of core and service inflation, which are, of course, closely linked, also hints that, at the start of the third quarter, consumer demand is not accelerating, at least on the services front. This is indirectly confirmed by the October business confidence survey for the services sector, which showed a clear slowdown in price change intentions for the next three months. The same indicator for manufactured goods pointed to stable pricing intentions.

In short, economic stagnation is bringing about a cooling of inflation that is unlikely to reverse sharply in the near term, unless there are unpredictable surprises in energy commodity prices.

As a result, we are revising down our forecast for average inflation in 2025 from 1.7% to 1.6%.
