data.title: eBay: Not Every Record Quarter Deserves A Rally
data.description:
Introduction

As the earnings season is in full swing, many companies have surprised the market either with unexpected misses—hello Fiserv, Inc. (FI) beats—cheers to Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN). One of the interesting stocks to look at is definitely eBay Inc. (EBAY). The company delivered a record quarter, yet the stock has dropped 15% on the cautious guidance and 2026 outlook from the management.

In this article, I want to break down the results and the company in general and to understand whether EBAY is a good investment opportunity. Hopefully, you will find something valuable in this piece for yourself as well.

Understanding eBay

I have a hard time understanding what’s going on with eBay. I went over their 10-Q, their earnings call, and their presentation, and while the results look fine, I can’t shake off the feeling that there’s something off.

eBay’s focus lately has shifted from being a platform for everything to narrowing down to its top categories, which mostly include car parts and accessories and trading cards. There are other things, of course, like handbags, sneakers, etc., but the first two seem to be the strongest either in absolute terms or in growth rate. So while I can see that these segments are growing very nicely for the company, I’m still struggling to understand what kind of business eBay really is today.

Their GMV is up by an impressive 8%, which is great, but at the same time, their gross profit margin has been going down over the last few years. So I don’t know what to make of it. The results look great, but at the same time, the overall situation is not perfect.

Focus Categories

Let’s start with the part of their business that I actually like—car parts and accessories. This is one of eBay’s biggest growth segments right now, contributing more than one percentage point to the company’s total GMV growth. They already have over 750 million listings just for parts and accessories, which makes it the largest online selection of unique auto parts in most major markets.

Motor parts and accessories, or P&A, was our second largest contributor to GMV growth in Q3, generating more than 1 point for the overall marketplace. The introduction of easy and free returns in the U.S. continued to build upon our trusted value proposition in P&A, while the cost and return rates for this program are well within our forecasted ranges. We continue to expand choice and selection in key inventory segments such as salvage and used parts, which help consumers find value at a time when many are stretched financially. Overall, we have over 750 million live P&A listings, which enables us to offer the largest online selection of unique auto parts and accessories in most of our major markets.

Probably, I like this part of eBay’s business the most because I have an understanding of how big this market could be and how profitable it is. One of my father’s businesses back in Ukraine is a shop where they dismantle used cars and sell the parts online similarly to how eBay’s platform works. It’s a different website, but you also have sellers listing items, buyers purchasing them, and the seller shipping the parts once ordered. It’s also a huge platform back in Ukraine, and every person has heard of it and most likely used it at least once.

It has been a great business in Ukraine, especially since the war started and people try to maintain their cars longer, but also before it worked out handsomely. So, I completely understand why this category does well in the U.S. as well. It’s a huge market. The population is layered, so not everyone replaces their car every few years, and the demand for affordable parts is always present.

A fact that is not directly related but interesting nonetheless: I live in Israel now, and my economics professor mentioned that Israel has one of the youngest vehicle fleets in the world. People here replace cars roughly every five years, and the used ones get shipped abroad. That’s definitely not the case in the U.S. According to Reuters, Americans now keep their cars for a record of 12.6 years on average, which is a substantial period of time. So this part of eBay’s business makes perfect sense to me, and I actually like it a lot.

But then there’s the other focus category—trading cards. I know this category has been growing for some time now, and I understand that there’s a collector market around it, but to me, it just sounds ridiculous. The company said that Pokémon GMV grew triple digits for the third straight quarter and that collectibles were its largest contributor to growth this time. This is something that makes me less attracted to this business, because it doesn’t sound sustainable to me personally. I genuinely can’t understand how someone can spend hundreds of dollars on a stack of cards that just sits on a shelf. Maybe it’s because I don’t have kids and don’t understand the fascination, but it just feels strange to me that one of eBay’s main growth engines depends on this.

Also, one of the new things they have is live trading events, with celebrities like Logan Paul or NBA players joining streams on eBay Live. Possibly, I don’t understand much about the target audience or the retail business, but this business segment looks very strange to me as well.

This brings me to eBay Live in general and their version of “live shopping.” I couldn’t write about it without trying it myself, and maybe it was a mistake. I thought it was bad. Again, maybe I’m not their target audience, but if this is supposed to be their big innovation, then it’s underwhelming. Each live stream has 20-80 viewers, and I don’t think it looks like a future growth driver.

They said eBay Live’s GMV run rate grew 5x year-over-year, but I just don’t see it. Maybe the numbers were minuscule, and now they are slightly bigger. That would make more sense. Maybe it works better for collectibles, but even then, it just feels like the company is forcing itself into trends that don’t really fit its platform.

AI Implementation

Now, the growth of the stock is directly correlated with the company's AI implementation. Here, I have some mixed feelings as well, because if I can relate to one part and justify the other, some of the developments that management is very vocal about don’t sound like something that will help this company in bringing in more clients or sales, for that matter.

eBay says it’s using AI for things like improving listings, powering recommendations, and even helping users search by photo. And while that all sounds nice, at the same time, it is not revolutionary. Google (GOOG) (GOOGL) has had image search for years, Pinterest, Inc. (PINS) has had visual search for years as well, and even when I knew it existed and tried it a few times, I never used it. So I am skeptical about the ability of this feature to attract more customers or to change the shopping experience.

It’s good that they’re finding ways to integrate AI, but I wouldn’t call them an “AI-driven company” because of it. Most of what they’re doing with AI just helps with listing descriptions and better recommendations. It’s an incremental improvement, which is needed, of course, to go toe-to-toe with the times, but it’s not revolutionary.

They also mentioned an AI shopping agent, an agentic commerce platform, and a large language model, or LLM, ecosystem. But again, that’s not something that will change how people perceive eBay. The only genuinely interesting feature, in my opinion, is that you can describe to AI what you’re searching for and get personalized product results. That could be useful, but I tried to find it myself on the website and couldn’t even locate the feature. Maybe it’s being tested in limited regions. So while I do think this is a smart direction, and I truly believe that in the future we’ll all shop by describing what we want to an AI assistant, I just don’t see eBay as the one leading that revolution.

Mixed Feelings About the Business

While I can recognize what eBay is doing well, I’m skeptical about how valuable it really is long-term. Their results were good—GMV up 8%, revenue up 8%, EPS up 14%, and their advertising business grew 23%. But their gross margin keeps shrinking and is now at 71.6%, down from 72.4% last year and from around 77% just a few years ago.

The company looks healthy, but profitability is slowly eroding. They returned $760 million to shareholders this quarter through buybacks and dividends. This is great, but I am still not feeling like eBay is a great buying opportunity for me.

Talking about the reasons for the stock drop, it’s mostly the fact that management said that the company may face headwinds for 2025 and 2026. They guided for fourth-quarter GMV growth of only 4%–6% (GMV in Q4 at $20.5 billion–$20.9 billion) and full-year GMV of ~5% growth. They flagged that last year’s trading cards and bullion surge created tough comparables, dragging future growth.

They also warned that elimination of the U.S. “de minimis” import exemption (meaning smaller cross-border parcels are now subject to tariffs) and other trade- and shipping-friction issues create structural headwinds for their cross-border business. Even though they say revenue and GMV will “grow positively,” the company admitted margin pressure will persist due to investments in shipping solutions, live commerce, and AI-agent platforms, plus interest expense drag from lower cash balances.

Valuation

What’s also interesting is that despite all of this, the company still trades at a relatively high valuation compared to its own history. Its current P/E ratio is around 15x, while its 5-year average is closer to 12x. For a secondhand marketplace with declining margins, that doesn’t look like a stock at a meaningful discount.

So while eBay is performing well financially, I can’t say that I would buy the stock at these levels. It’s not an AI company, and it’s not the future of e-commerce. It’s a decent business that found some stable niches, but nothing that makes me think it will change the world. If nothing groundbreaking is happening, why would this stock trade at a much higher multiple?

Conclusion

So, to sum it up, I see the good, I see the effort, and I even see smart decisions. But I also see a company trying to present itself as something it’s not. And I just can’t convince myself that these “AI” features, or live shopping experiments, or trading cards, are the foundation of long-term value for eBay Inc. For me, this company is simply okay.

data.title: Palantir: The AI Reality Check Investors Can't Ignore
data.description:
The Palantir (PLTR) stock has gained more than 163% this year. As discussed in our previous coverage on the stock, its valuation upsurge is not only a result of mere AI hype. Instead, it reflects reward for Palantir’s consistent delivery of tangible progress in scaling profitability, as its Artificial Intelligence Platform (“AIP”) accelerates capitalization on emerging secular opportunities. This is corroborated by the company’s two consecutive quarters of raised full year 2025 revenue guidance, which now reflects 45% y/y growth at the midpoint to $4.146 billion.

The recent partnership to integrate AIP with Nvidia’s (NVDA) tech stack has only reinforced optimism over Palantir’s AI monetization strategy. Momentum in the current quarter is also supported by Palantir’s increasing traction in government opportunities – especially in Europe, where accelerating adoption is helping narrow its international operations’ growth gap from core U.S. public sector opportunities. Specifically, U.S. government opportunities have been a key driver of Palantir’s acceleration this year, thanks to the favourable defense tech spending environment under the Trump administration.

Taken together, the developments continue to bolster Palantir’s translation of imminent secular AI tailwinds into tangible demand visibility and scalability, underpinning durability to its valuation trajectory. The following analysis will explore defining questions that will drive Palantir’s upcoming Q3 earnings results—including the growth trajectory that the market is pricing into Palantir’s 268x estimated earnings multiple, and whether its execution across the commercial and government segments is consistent with those expectations.

What Does The Market Expect From Palantir?

Following its eye-watering upsurge this year, the stock’s become one of the most expensive at 268x estimated earnings and 98x estimated sales. Within the software peer group, Clearwater Analytics (CWAN) has the most comparable forward growth outlook (2025E: +61% y/y; 2026E: +30% y/y) to Palantir (2025E: +45% y/y; 2026E: +35% y/y). Yet Clearwater Analytics trades at a much lower multiple of 31x forward earnings and 6x forward sales.

The main difference is in the durability of their respective multi-year growth and earnings accretion trajectories. Clearwater Analytics’ growth outlook is expected to decelerate into the high-teens percentage range by 2027, representing a 19% five-year CAGR through 2030. This compares with Palantir’s 36% five-year CAGR over the same period based on current consensus estimates. Meanwhile, Clearwater Analytics’ earnings outlook, though robust, also pales in comparison to Palantir’s. The company is expected to expand earnings at a 24% five-year CAGR through 2030, versus Palantir’s 35% over the same period.

This accordingly highlights the market’s optimism for Palantir’s unmatched scalability, which is critical for cash flow accretion underpinning the stock’s valuation outlook.

To further gauge the durability of Palantir’s premium valuation multiple given its current estimates, we’ve also performed a reverse discounted cash flow (“DCF”) analysis. This is performed to gauge whether the pace of revenue and earnings growth predictions are supportive of an intrinsic value that aligns with Palantir’s current valuation multiple premium on a relative basis to peers.

Similar to our last reverse DCF analysis performed on the stock, key valuation assumptions considered include a perpetual growth rate of 3.5% applied on projected 2035 cash flow to firm (i.e., EBITDA + change in net working capital + cash taxes) in determining Palantir’s terminal value. The perpetual growth rate of 3.5% is in line with the anticipated pace of long-term economic expansion across Palantir’s core operating regions (i.e., U.S. and allied regions). This accordingly reflects the rate at which its steady-state cash flows – which is proxied by 2035 projections consistent with the anticipated timeline to a mature business cycle – can sustainably expand at over the longer-term.

The reverse DCF analysis also considers a 9.0% WACC, which is used to discount the cash flow projections and estimated terminal value over a 10-year forecast period to determine Palantir’s enterprise value. Net debt – which in Palantir’s case is its cash balance due to nil borrowings – is added back to arrive at its equity value.

Assuming Palantir maintains a similar pace of quarterly margin expansion as observed over the past two years, underpinned by AIP’s rapid scalability alongside complementary improvements to operating leverage, the stock’s current price at ~$195 per share (October 30 close) implies a multi-year revenue and earnings growth trajectory of at least 35% and 44%, respectively:

See here for enlarged diagrams: Palantir_-_Supplemental_Information.pdf

Based on the reverse DCF analysis, the implied growth trajectory for Palantir is in line with the current pace of consensus growth estimates. This corroborates that Palantir’s premium valuation multiple on a relative basis to peers is currently supported by the intrinsic value of its cash flow projections.

Is This Multi-Year Growth Trajectory Supported By Recent Developments?

We believe the recent developments at Palantir reinforce demand visibility that corroborates current growth estimates underpinning its valuation, both on a relative (i.e. multiple-based) and intrinsic (i.e., DCF) basis:

Palantir Integration With Nvidia Tech Stack

Earlier this week, Palantir announced that its proprietary Ontology – the digital replica of an organization that underpins Foundry, Gotham, and AIP’s insight-driving capabilities – will integrate Nvidia’s AI tech stack. This will allow Ontology access to Nvidia’s AI models and accelerated compute power to further address enterprise AI needs, and bolster Palantir’s penetration into related commercial opportunities – especially in the industrial vertical, given their complex supply chains and need for dynamic systems.

Specifically, the industrial vertical is inherently low-margin due to its capital intensity. Yet AI is able to unlock greater product efficiency and better decision-making, enabling productivity gains (e.g., reduced downtime; supply chain optimization) that can have a tangible impact on industrials’ scalability.

This accordingly makes industrials a key emerging vertical for AI application. As part of a recent industry survey, only about 21% of respondents have cited adoption of industrial AI solutions, while almost half expect implementation over the next three years, driven by supply chain optimization needs. The emerging opportunity is also consistent with current industry estimates for the industrial AI market opportunity to exceed $150 billion in value by 2030, representing a 23% CAGR from about $44 billion in 2024. This accordingly highlights the significant growth headroom for Palantir’s commercial AIP monetization in the industrial vertical. And the recent collaboration with Nvidia is expected to further Palantir’s reach into said opportunity, as it’s expected to unlock further optimization critical for the industrial end-market. It’s also expected to complement Palantir’s Warp Speed operating system optimized for manufacturing and industrial verticals, which further reinforces its longer-term commercial demand visibility.

Expanding Europe Footprint

The U.K. has been consistently a key growth driver for Palantir’s international business – especially in public sector opportunities in recent quarters. And recent developments are expected to further expand Palantir’s international government momentum, as it bolsters reach into additional European opportunities:

  • £1.5 Billion U.K. Investment: Earlier last month, Palantir announced its pledge of £1.5 billion towards U.K. investments by 2030, targeting the development of next-generation AI defense technologies. It’s also been awarded a £750 million, five-year contract with the U.K. Ministry of Defense to deploy its proprietary AI-enabled defense technology. This is expected to extend the company’s current momentum in the region’s public sector opportunities, and drive further accretion to government segment growth.
  • Hadean Partnership: Palantir announced its partnership with Hadean, a leading U.K. defense tech provider, earlier this month. The collaboration is expected to further Palantir’s share of defense AI tech spend in the region beyond direct engagements acquired through U.K. Ministry of Defense contracts.
  • Letter of Intent with Poland Ministry of National Defense: Palantir and Poland’s Defense Ministry has signed a letter of intent earlier this week to support the agency’s expansion of its data, AI, and cybersecurity capabilities. This accordingly reinforces Palantir’s foray in Europe public sector opportunities—a region that CEO Alex Karp has long criticized for its slow development and adoption of AI software. Specifically, Poland is expecting $55 billion in defense spending next year, which represents 5% of its GDP – the largest allocation among NATO constituents.
  • NATO Adoption of Maven Smart System: Earlier this year, NATO adopted Palantir’s proprietary Maven Smart System. This represents a critical “landing” deal for Palantir, as it gains access to “deploy its AI mission command solution across [NATO’s] 32 member states.” True to Palantir’s “land and expand” business model, the NATO partnership is a critical step towards further penetration of opportunities across Europe, and increased visibility into its international government segment’s long-term growth trajectory. This was likely a precursor to the recent letter of intent signed with Poland, signaling confidence in continued adoption of Palantir’s defense tech offerings among U.S. allies in Europe.

U.S. Policy Support

Palantir has emerged as one of the leading defense tech firms as the U.S. Army undergoes modernization. This has been further bolstered by the Trump administration’s policy support. Specifically, the One Big Beautiful Act Bill now includes significant allocations towards defense spending, with “tens of billions of dollars in funding for innovation priorities.”

Recent commentary from the U.S. Army Chief Information Officer, Leonel Garciga, has also reaffirmed Palantir’s “foundational” role in the agency’s AI strategy:

Palantir is a core platform for business capabilities and readiness right now, to lay the foundation for some of the AI work that we want to do across the Army.

Source: U.S. Army CIO Leonel Garciga, Bloomberg News

This accordingly creates a favourable backdrop for Palantir, as long-term U.S. government opportunities represent a key growth driver for the business. The company’s increasingly entrenched role in bolstering the U.S. Army’s AI ecosystem is also expected to complement its moat in defense tech, and reinforce its reach into international opportunities among allied regions.

Resilient Enterprise AI Software Spending

Palantir’s U.S. commercial operations represent its leading growth driver. The unit delivered 93% y/y revenue growth in Q2, complemented by continued acceleration in commercial-driven remaining performance obligations at 77% y/y growth during the period.

This accordingly provides strong accretion required to maintain the 36%+ multi-year growth trajectory currently priced into Palantir’s valuation. And the momentum is expected to stay resilient, given strong indicators of enterprise AI software spending ahead.

A recent CIO survey conducted by RBC Capital Markets shows that software will represent the bulk of near-term IT budgets. Almost all surveyed respondents have indicated expectations for increased software spend through the year, with the majority of allocations designated towards “AI and cybersecurity, followed by Data Warehouse, Analytics, and BI and Database and IT Service Management software” – a strong tailwind for Palantir as it continues to scale AIP deployment in the commercial sector:

What Can Go Wrong?

Looming macroeconomic uncertainties remain the key overhang for Palantir, as it directly interferes with the enterprise IT spending environment. However, as discussed in the earlier section, AI spending – which Palantir is a key beneficiary of – remains resilient. This is further reinforced by AI-promised productivity gains, which can help businesses – particularly those in capital-intensive industrial and manufacturing verticals – preserve margins amid adverse cost pressures stemming from ongoing tariff uncertainties.

Another downside risk facing Palantir is its increasing exposure to political controversies. For instance, the company has been outspoken about its support for Israel amid the ongoing conflict in Gaza. It’s also played a key role in supporting the Trump administration’s ongoing immigration crackdown efforts. Both of which have been controversial topics in which Americans have been divided on.

In the latest development, Palantir’s Head of Global Communications, Lisa Gordon, has also identified the company’s “political shift toward the Trump administration [as] concerning”. From an operating perspective, this could risk boycotts and lead to adverse implications on its commercial segment growth outlook. Similar challenges have been recently observed at companies like Tesla (TSLA), Netflix (NFLX) and Disney (DIS), as their political views conflict with demand drivers.

Final Thoughts

Taken together, there is tangible support for Palantir’s current valuation, despite the significant premium on a relative basis to peers. Recent developments – spanning the integration of AIP with Nvidia’s AI tech stack, accelerating adoption across U.S. and international governments, and resilient enterprise software spending allocations – reinforce visibility into Palantir’s multi-year, high growth trajectory, which strengthens its prospects for sustained margin expansion at scale.

Specifically, the company’s expanding collaborations with U.S. allies, such as NATO, alongside its deepening partnerships with enterprise leaders further skew its opportunities to the upside. Not only do these newly secured relationships represent standalone opportunities, but they also provide validation to Palantir’s technologies, and signal incremental avenues for growth expansion and market share penetration headroom – aligning closely with its land-and-expand business model.

Coupled with resilience in the enterprise IT spending environment, alongside favourable policy support for defense tech modernization, Palantir enters its upcoming Q3 earnings update in a position of strength. Fundamentally, the company also continues to deliver tangible financial progress, underpinned by consistent revenue acceleration and operating leverage improvements. This accordingly enhances durability to its valuation trajectory, while keeping investors’ optimism over the company’s long-term AI moat intact.

data.title: A Failed Acquisition Is The Best Thing That's Happened To Core Scientific
data.description:
This is a big week for markets, in every sense of the word: the Fed decision Wednesday afternoon, several trillion dollars worth of companies reporting, and, of course, a highly anticipated U.S.-China trade deal. There’s one more big headline this week worth paying attention to: the shareholder vote on CoreWeave, Inc.’s (CRWV) acquisition of Core Scientific, Inc. (CORZ).

Consistent with our expectations, CoreWeave did not receive the requisite number of votes for the acquisition to pass. The stock gained over 6% on the news, intra-trading on Thursday. The failed acquisition isn't all that surprising, given the trajectory of events heading into Thursday's vote, with proxy advisors Glass Lewis and ISS advising against it (reports that CoreWeave CEO Michael Intrator called it disappointing). We think this is the best thing that could've happened to Core Scientific and see a big opportunity in Core Scientific on its fall-through.

Details of CoreWeave’s $9B bid for Core Scientific & why today's news is good:

CoreWeave, Wall Street’s favorite neocloud baby, announced back in June its intention to acquire Core Scientific in a $9B all-stock deal. Upon closing, Core Scientific stockholders would receive 0.1235 newly issued shares of CoreWeave Class A common stock. Back in June, neither stock reacted well to the news, with CoreWeave dropping 3% and Core Scientific pulling back 18%. The less-than-impressed reaction was not on the acquisition itself as much as it was about the $9B price tag, undervaluing Core Scientific and working more in favor of CoreWeave, plus concerns over ownership dilution with more shares. The deal would shave off $10B in future lease obligations for CoreWeave, according to the acquisition presentation. The way CoreWeave CEO put it: “We’re not paying rent, right, for the next 15 years.”

For reference, CoreWeave is already Core Scientific's largest customer, so CoreWeave would essentially be buying its landlord, saving on rent for years to come. So, CoreWeave would be securing an AI fuel line that’ll enable it to enter more lease agreements, similar to the $14B AI infrastructure deal we saw with Meta Platforms (META) last month. It would also be a relatively easy way for CoreWeave to secure extra capacity without high cost; in fact, Core Scientific’s vertical integration is expected to result in $500M in annual cost savings by the end of 2027.

This wouldn’t be too bad of a setup, if not for the fact that Core Scientific’s external opportunity is outpacing the one associated with this deal. Core Scientific sits on approximately 1.3 GW of gross power capacity, of which 840 MW is allocated to CoreWeave and 250 MW of billable IT capacity remains available, with potential expansion for an additional 1 GW. In comparison, Applied Digital (APLD) has about 800 MW across Polaris Forge 1 and 2, and is already leasing out capacity within the development pipeline. The capacity Core Scientific has is notable and has been overshadowed by acquisition concerns this year. We expect investors to recognize Core Scientific's standalone potential now that the deal is off the table, as there is greater value in its uncontracted power capacity.

Core Scientific also reported its Q3 '25 results during the week, with revenue of $81.1M, up from $78.6M last quarter but down from $95.4M in the year-ago quarter, with a contracted net loss of $146.7M versus $455.3M in the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $3.9M, up from a loss of $0.2M a year ago.

We think the top line isn’t moving due to the weight of the shift to high-density colocation business (HPC hosting or HDC), allocating more capacity to HPC over mining bitcoin. This quarter, the bitcoin mined dropped 55%, and the average bitcoin price (BTC-USD) increased 88%. HDC sales were up 45.6% Q/Q to $10.3M, while bitcoin-mining business sales were $66.1M, down 22% Y/Y.

The market didn’t react too well to the results, but we believe they confirm that management is continuing the push toward AI infrastructure leasing and away from bitcoin. The only concern we have is about the trajectory of CapEx if the acquisition does not go through, considering that $196.4 of the $244.5 was funded by CoreWeave. What eases our concern is that we don't see CoreWeave stepping back from funding the shift toward HDC, considering it remains reliant on Core Scientific capacity.

Our thesis on Core Scientific isn’t risk-free. This could place risk on their future positioning with CoreWeave, although that cannot be proved or disproved this early. What we do know is that CoreWeave is likely already looking for another bitcoin mining turned AI infrastructure play to buy because the cost of converting a cryptocurrency site is lower than setting up a whole new campus. We expect shareholders will focus less on Intrator and more on Core Scientific’s standalone potential value.

Valuation is cheap compared to the potential premium

The digital infrastructure landlord scene has evolved very quickly, and it’s looking more attractive for Core Scientific to join its bitcoin mining-turned-AI infrastructure peer group in the opportunity of securing lease agreements beyond CoreWeave. The results of Google (GOOGL) (GOOG) and Meta Platforms (META) after the bell on Wednesday confirm that CapEx spend focused on AI build-out is expanding, and Core Scientific is uniquely positioned to benefit as an unrealized, high-capacity option. Applied Digital and IREN (IREN), for example, are monetizing the opportunity, building out capacity, and the stock price is reflecting it, as shown below, while Core Scientific is underperforming the peer group.

Core Scientific stock has run up recently to its 52-week high on the deal's failure, hitting $22.12 per share. RSI is almost 69, heading toward overbought territory. Valuation-wise, the stock remains attractive in our opinion. The stock trades at a forward EV/Sales of 17.93x against a group average of 3.61x, which looks high at first until checking the more direct peer group, shown below on the six-month chart. Core Scientific’s premium is arguably negligible against the premium it could go into if it realizes more lease agreements on its power potential.

Bottom Line:

This is a kind of caterpillar turning into a butterfly scenario, and we’re here at the right time. Core Scientific has ample opportunity to lease more capacity and expand its operations. We see substantial upside for Core Scientific on Thursday's rejection, and hence we are initiating coverage on Core Scientific with a Buy.
